page.title: 05Cottesmore Then and Now
page.content: Cottesmore was once called Cott's Moor.On a Sunday people would go to church and leave their meat, if they had any,cooking in the bakehouse.The local shop Stricklands is now where the bakehouse used to be.The lane near Stricklands is called Clatterpot Lane because the drinking water came from a pump in in the bakehouse yard,and when people put their buckets down they made a big clatter.There were two mills one in Mill Street,which was then called Sheepdyke and another one in Wenton Close.Mill Street was called Sheepdyke because of the ditch where they dipped the sheep.They used to put disinfectant in it,then push the sheep through and out the other end.The villagers used it free, outsiders were charged.It was filled in,in 1950.The road to the camp was called Rogues' Lane because of the gypsies' camp.
